metadata.title: Pre- or post-TiCl4 treated TiO2 nano-array photoanode for QDSSC: Ti self- doping, flat-band level and electron diffusion length

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Applied Surface Science
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/apsusc
Full length article
Pre- or post-TiCl4 treated TiO2 nano-array photoanode for QDSSC: Ti3+ selfdoping, flat-band level and electron diffusion length
Dongqi Li, Zhaohua Jiang, Qixing Xia, Zhongping Yao⁎
School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, State Key Laboratory of Urban Water Resource and Environment, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin 150001, China
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: TiCl4 treatment Photoanode Electron transfer capability Ti3+ self-doping
A B S T R A C T
Of the photoanode in QDSSC, the TiCl4 solution treatment is widely used in mesoporous TiO2 surface modification. However, device performance amplification and electron transfer capability improvement of the two common pre- or post treatment are seldom yet. In this work, we explore the TiCl4 different treatments based on the typical TiO2 nanowire array photoanode for CdSxSe1-x QDSSC. In terms of the changes of electron transfer pathway, flat-band potential (Vfb) and charge carrier concentration (ND), we explored the inducement and increase of electron transfer capability and efficacy under different treatments. As for the influence of device performance, the more negative Vfb (−0.315 V, NHE) and higher ND (7.63× 1019 cm−3) of PBS are beneficial to the increase of open-circuit voltage (Voc) and short-circuit current (Jsc). Therefore, the TiCl4 pre-treatment on photoanode modification (in PBS) is beneficial to reduce the resistances of charge transfer and recombination. The cell performance of PBS in CdSxSe1-x QD sensitization was improved significantly: the PCE was 7.54%, the Jsc was 18.93mA/cm2, Voc was 0.78 V and fill factor (FF) was 51.1%.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Exploiting quantum dots (QDs) as light-harvest sensitizers demonstrates a promising technology in low-cost solar energy conversion for their advantages, as band-gap tunability, high mechanical flexibility and multiple exciton generation possibilities. Profiting from the expanding spectrum adsorption of QD sensitizers, the engineering for charge transfer pathway and energy band matching of photoanode is crucial to decide the efficacy for electron injection and exportation for solar cell. Of the typical n-type conduction materials, the TiO2 semiconductor is applied as a promising electron transfer electrode of photoanode for solar cell, such as the large bandgap, high surface activity, mechanical flexibility, solution processing and high chemical stability [1–3].
The morphology engineering for photoanode is served to manage the transfer pathway for electron efficient injection and exportation. Of the pathway modification, cumulated mesoporous layers are the common electron transfer skeleton (TS) of QDSSC, such as the typical P25 microspheres [4–6] and one-dimensional nanowires [7,8], in which the concentrated accumulation could maximized adsorb photo sensitizers. Furthermore, compared with the cumulated mesoporous layer, the vertical well-organized nanowire array (nanorod or nanofiber) assures the electron oriented transfer, of which the highly crystalline continuous nano-structure could overcome the charge quenching
and hysteretic by the surface states of mesoporous layer [9–11]. On the other hand, the increase for charge carrier concentration and
reduction for bandgap are beneficial to increase the drive force and loading capacity of electron. Many strategies have been used to develop the capability of electron transfer, including energy-level adjustment by elements doping and considerable electron injection. Generally, of element doping into TiO2 lattice, the non-metal like N [12], B [13] and F [14] introduced the energy states to matching bandgap, and metal like Zn [15,16] and Sn [17] diminished the defect states and increased the electron density. Of the modification for electron injection, the modifiers were mostly provided with strong reducibility and electrondonor to increase the electron carrier density, such as metal hydrides [18,19], n-type inorganic materials compositing [20] and carbon-material hybridization [21,22].
Several researches have detected that the emergence of oxygen vacancy in titanium dioxide is accompanied with Ti3+, which has no foreign elements doping and thereby is named as self-doping. The doping of oxygen vacancies and Ti3+ is confirmed to change the electronic structure, energy level and electron carrier concentration for TiO2 [23,24]. Liu et al. found the sub-bandgap was established and the mono-energetic occupied intrinsic gap states was identified about 0.7 eV below TiO2 CB edge, which was mostly ascribed to the self-doped Ti3+. The increased photocatalytic activity was attributed to the light excitation on gap-states by self-doping for water oxidation [25]. Zhu
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.apsusc.2019.06.166 Received 18 December 2018; Received in revised form 10 June 2019; Accepted 16 June 2019
⁎ Corresponding author. E-mail address: yaozhongping@hit.edu.cn (Z. Yao).
Applied Surface Science 491 (2019) 319–327
Available online 17 June 2019 0169-4332/ © 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
T
et al. reported that the concentration of Ti3+ was relevant to the formation of impurity state and the localized oxygen defect states by scarce doping would affect the electron recombining and quenching [26]. Wang et al. revealed the doped Ti3+ could depress the recombination of electrons and holes and enhance photocatalytic performance [27]. Of the modification by Ti3+ self-doping, the increased capability of charge separation and electron transfer for photoanode were attributed by the increased electron concentration and narrow bandgap, generally. Besides, the self-doping in modification states, such as strong reduction [28,29], gas or thermal treatment [30,31] and plasma treatment [32,33], are more even to the foreign elements doping, which led the uniform increase for electron transfer.
TiCl4 treatment on TiO2 electron transfer layer (ETL) is a general strategy to increase ETL electron transfer efficacy and reduce charge recombination, widely used in photoanode modification for various sensitized solar cell [34–38]. Of which, the significant improvement of device performance has been observed on the common post- treatment on mesoporous TiO2 surface, such as the device PCE of 12.4% to 15.6% for MAPbI3-xClx PSC [39], 5.18% to 7.20% for DSSC [40], 0.87% to 2.13% for simple CdSe QDSSC [41]. While, some researches treated meso-TiO2 in advance to fabricate the overall layer functioning as the blocking layer (BL) [42,43]. According to the pathway changes in the process of electron transfer of the modified photoanode, the improved performance was attributed to the deposited amorphous TiO2 nanocrystal, which is considered to increase the surface area of meso-TiO2 film [40] and avoid the direct ohmic contact of conduction substrate and electrolyte as BL [41]. However, in the pre- and post-treatment process, the difference of developed cell performance is confused yet. And furthermore, in addition to the morphology and crystalline modification, the discussion on inducement and increase of electron transfer capability variation with pre-treatment is required.
In this work, the ETLs of typical TiO2 nanowire array were established by hydrothermal preparation and treated in different TiCl4 preand post-treatment (PBS and IBS). In terms of the changes of electron transfer pathway, flat-band potential (Vfb) and charge carrier concentration (ND), we explored the improvement of electron transfer capability and efficacy under different treatments. Meanwhile, of PBS structure, the more introduced Ti3+ increases electron concentration and narrows bandgap, which is beneficial to the improvement of electron transfer capability. As for the influence of device performance, the more negative Vfb (−0.315 V, NHE) and higher ND (7.63×1019 cm−3) of PBS are beneficial to the increase of open-circuit voltage (Voc) and short-circuit current (Jsc) of cell performance. The cell performance of PBS in one-step optimized CdSxSe1-x QD sensitization was improved significantly: the PCE was 7.54%, Jsc was 18.93mA/cm2, Voc was 0.78 V and fill factor (FF) was 51.1%. The electron transfer capability with different treatments on photoanode would provide additional supplementation for the fabrication of TiO2 photoanode in other sensitized solar cell.

sections.heading: 2.1. Preparation of TiO2 photoanode
sections.text:
The nano-thick blocking layer (BL) over various substrate of clean FTO glass (sheet resistance 13 ± 1.5Ω/sq., DHS-FTO22-15N, Hepta Chroma, China) or nanowire skeleton was prepared in chemical bath deposition (CBD) of facile TiCl4 treatment [35]. TiCl4 precursor was prepared in ice condition and then controlled hydrolysis 0.5 h at 70 °C heating. The products were washed with deionized water for several times. The TiO2 crystal nucleation and growth of TiCl4 CBD treatment was in control of external temperature. The hydrolyzation was suppressed in ice and then motivated after heating. Ti precursor light bluish solution preserved in the ice water was prepared in low concentration of 20, 40 and 60mmol/L (named BL-20 etc.).
The nanowire array transfer skeleton (TS) was prepared in a
modified hydrothermal method [44]. The Ti precursor was prepared by mixing 1.67mL Tetrabutyl titanate (TBOT, 99.5%) in 100mL hydrochloric acid aqueous solution (50% volume fraction) and 10 h aging at room temperature. The light yellow precursor and substrate of clean FTO glass or TiO2 blocking layer were transferred to Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was heated at 180 °C for 5 h and the cooled down with furnace. The films were washed with deionized water and without annealing treatment.

sections.heading: 2.2. The fabrication of CdSxSe1-x QDSSC
sections.text:
The sensitized photoanodes were prepared with neotype optimized CdSxSe1-x QDs using the one-step Successive Ionic Layer Adsorption and Reaction (SILAR) method as the report [45]. In brief, the TiO2 film was first dipped into the cationic solution with dissolution of zinc acetate and cadmium acetate in DI water, and then rinsed thoroughly with methanol and dried up. Subsequently, the film was immersed into the anionic solution with dissolution of NaBH4, Na2S·9H2O and Se powder in 50% methanol aqueous solutions, then rinsed thoroughly with methanol and dried up; this procedure formed one SILAR cycle. The sensitized photoanode by one-pot CdSxSe1-x QD is passivated with the ZnSe/ZnS layer over the photo activators. And the optimized photoanodes were sensitized when SILAR deposition exceeded 6 cycles.
The all-inorganic QDSSCs were fabricated by encapsulating the polysulfide electrolyte between the each above-mentioned photoanode and the counter electrode. Each solar cell was constructed by assembling the Cu2S/brass counter electrode and QD-sensitized TiO2 electrode with a binder clip separated by a 50 μm thickness Scotch spacer. Polysulfide electrolyte solution was then filled inside. The counter electrode Cu2S/brass was obtained by immersing brass foil in 30% HCl solution at 70 °C for 40min and then immersed in the polysulfide electrolyte solution for 10min. As the systematical analysis reported of the effect of methanol ratio on device performance [46], the enhancement of performance is consistent with increased concentration of methanol. The composition of the electrolyte solution were all-inorganic and consists of 2.0 M Na2S, 2.0M sulfur, and 0.2M KCl in methanol and distilled water of 7: 3 [47]. A copper mask with a window of 5× 5mm2 was clipped on the back of each photoanode to normalize the active area of the cells. The XRD patterns and SEM image of counter electrode were shown as Fig. S1.

sections.heading: 2.3. Structural characterizations
sections.text: X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of all samples were collected at room temperature by a Rigaku D/max-γB diffraction meter with Cu Kα radiation at 30 kV and 30mA in the 2θ range from 20° to 90°. The morphology of the samples was characterized with field-emission scanning electron microscope (SEM; Nano Lab 600i). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) were carried out on a FEI Tecnai G2 F30 instrument. The transmittance and Ultra Violet–visible (UV–vis) absorbance spectra of different films were recorded on an UV–vis spectrophotometer (Lambda XLS, PerkinElmer). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) were measured by a Phi-5700 spectroscopy (ESCA system, USA) using a monochromatic Al Kα X-ray source (1486.6 eV) operating at 15 kV. The binding energy was calibrated by taking C1s peak at 284.6 eV.

sections.heading: 2.4. Electrochemical evaluation
sections.text:
Mott-Schottky tests of photoanodes and J-V characteristic curves of the series QDSSCs were measured using a CHI 660E electrochemical workstation (Chenhua Instrument, Shanghai, China). Of which, the M-S curves were tested in darkness and the cells were illuminated by a AM 1.5 G, 100mW/cm2 150W xenon lamp class ABB solar simulator (PLSSXE300, Perfectlight, China). The main wavelength range of the Xe lamp with the strongest irradiation was between 250 and 800 nm. In all
cases, the electrolyte solutions were purged with Ar, and the measurement was carried out under an Ar atmosphere in the hermetically closed electrochemical cell.
Impedance spectra were measured at equilibrium potential of sensitized photoanodes in the frequency range 0.01 Hz to 1MHz with 5mVAC amplitude, assembled in a conventional system as solar cells. The iterated simulation of circuit fitting was evaluated using Zview (Scribner) software. The reference electrode was Ag/AgCl (sat. KCl) and the counter electrode was brass/Cu2S for experiments in polysulfide electrolyte consists of 2.0M Na2S, 2.0 M sulfur, and 0.2 M KCl in methanol and distilled water of 7:3.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussions
sections.text:
The cross-sectional images of BLs prepared in different concentration are shown in Fig. 1a–c. The ultra-thin BLs grew on FTO compactly and tightly, the thickness of which is fine controlled on nanoscale after FTO subtraction (Fig. 1d). Likewise, the transmittance spectra in Fig. S2 also exhibit the nanoscale thinness and the BLs in several solutions of which are almost over 80%, similar to the bare FTO glass. In addition, the layer thickness rises and the surface roughens with the solution concentration increase (Fig. S3). The thinnest BL-20 is about 50 nm thick and level smooth. The thickness and surface variations are determined by the miniature crystal growth in the process of titanium coordination condensation. It is reported that smaller Ti coordination ion formed when TiCl4 solution used that [Ti (OH)n (H2O)6-n] (4−n)+ (n=2, 3) and [Tin (OH)2n (H2O)2n]2n+ (n=1) [48–50]. In ice condition, the hydrolyzation of Ti dual-core or multi-core hydroxyl complexes is suppressed. After heating, speedy nucleation consumes the slim Ti coordination ion in micro-domain, which leads the crystal growth much lower than the nucleation. Therefore, lower concentration improves the deposited TiO2 infiltration and surface smoother.
The chemical composition of thin BLs of different concentration is analyzed in X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). According to the high resolution XPS spectra of Ti 2p in Fig. 2a, the differences of Ti 2p3/
2 and 2p1/2 peaks are appreciable, that the peaks high binding energy shift with the concentration increase. The details of peaks fitting are listed in Table S1, of which the BL-20, the Ti 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 peak are 458.61 eV and 464.31 eV, respectively. It can be noted that more low valence Ti ion (Ti3+ or Ti2+) is self-doped in BLs of diluted solution [51,52], which leads the oxygen vacancy production and improves the capability of photoelectron collection [53]. The VO·· energy level caused by self-doped Ti3+ reduces the conduction band of TiO2 BL, and the bandgap decreases. In addition, proved as the absorbance spectra of the different BLs in Fig. 2b, the redshift absorption edge by decreased bandgap exhibits that the BL of lower concentration is beneficial to the electron transition and the extension of sunlight active absorption range. Therefore, smooth BL-20 has a better performance of the electron collection and capability of light absorption, which makes the ultra-thin BL-20 as the choice to adjust the energy level of the complete photoanode.
The TiCl4 treatment on photoanode was achieved in two designs. One was controlling nanowire array skeleton growth over the smooth blocking layer above, named paved BL-TS (PBS). And the other was depositing overall layer stuffing into the bottom clearance of the transport skeleton made in advance, named infilled BL-TS (IBS). Of the two photoanode, the TS nanowire array was fabricated in a facile hydrothermal method and the following BL was prepared as above BL-20. Fig. 3 is the cross-sectional and top-view SEM images of two kinds BLTS structures. Of the PBS structure in Fig. 3a–b, the BL is flatten and thin and vertical skeleton is about 2.47 μm long. The nanowire TS over BL growth is bundle-shaped. The regular nanowire array TS over ultrathin-smooth BL bilayer exhibits a distinct division and supplies an oriented transfer pathway for photogenerated electron.
While, of the IBS structure in Fig. 3c–d, the post-infilled BL was not deposited at the bottom clearance of nanowire TS as expected. Two functional layers structure (IBS) are mixed and no distinct bilayer structure. The cross-linked layer by TiCl4 post-treatment spoils the orderliness of nanowire array, and thin membrane-shaped structure grows covered over the upper surface or stuffed in the mid-clearance of
given nanowire TS irregularly. The nanowire each is blurred and functions as if the cumulated meso-TiO2, increasing the disorderliness of transfer pathway for electron exportation. According to the epitaxy growth in the CBD process of BL preparation, the cross-linked film over nanowire is attributed to the Ti hydroxyl coordination ion oxolation in the process of Ti precursor hydrolyzation [49,54]. Besides, the nanowire lateral surface has much more active site and the surface states increase the probability of oxolation. In consideration of the Ti precursor oxolation route that Ti-OH converts to Ti-O-Ti, the oxolation is easier to carry on TiO2 skeleton surface.
Fig. 4 is the XRD patterns and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) image for the composition analysis of different BL-TSs and nanowire structures. As the XRD patterns in Fig. 4a, the BL and BL-TS structures present the typical peaks of rutile TiO2, related to the facets
(110), (101) and (002) (JCPDS 21-1276). It can be seen that (002) is the host facet, perpendicular to the facet (110). Besides, the TEM image in Fig. 4b shows the morphology of nanowire skeleton and the average diameter of nanowires is about 50 nm. From the high resolution TEM image, the interplanar spacing is 0.296 nm, which is corresponding to the host crystal facet (001) of rutile TiO2 in XRD patterns (parallel facet of (002)). Therefore, the nanowire growth is preferentially oriented along with the [001] direction and TiO2 facet (001) is the host crystal of the nanowire skeleton as our past work [55]. Meanwhile, the pre- and post-treatment (PBS and IBS) are both beneficial to crystallinity improvement.
Primordial TiO2 as the n-type semiconductor, the Fermi level location is quite close to lower edge of the conduction band. When the TiO2 pristine photoanode are under illumination with sunlight, the charge is
generated and electron and hole is separated, thereby the Fermi level splitting into quasi-Fermi levels simultaneously [56]. The electron concentration (ND) and the Fermi level location, related to the flat-band potential (Vfb), exhibit the electron generation and transition capacity of semiconductor. The Mott-Schottky measurement is conducted to evaluate the Vfb and charge carrier concentration (ND). When MottSchottky measurement is performed, the BL-TS semiconductor is in contact with the solution where a redox couple is present. Then, an exchange of electrons can occur in order to match the two Fermi energies (Vfb and Vredox) immediately [57–59]. The Mott-Schottky equation reads:
⎜ ⎟= ⎛ ⎝ ⎞ ⎠ ⎛ ⎝ − − ⎞ ⎠C eε ε N V V kT e 1 2 sc r D f2 0 b (1)
where Csc is capacitance of the space-charge region, e is the electron charge, ε0 is the dielectric vacuum permittivity, εr is the dielectric constant of semiconductor, k is Boltzmann's constant, and T is the temperature.
The Mott-Schottky curves contain two to three linear regions with different slopes in accordance with the n-type semiconductor behavior under increased bias. The capacitance decrease when the anodic bias is increased to flat band potential, which leads the generation of electronhole pairs. The decrease behavior is caused by all donor levels but not one specific level until capacitance is stabilized [60]. The two sloped curves are caused by titania films grown on FTO or other semiconductors [61]. The voltage region next to Vfb manifests the semiconductor properties of MOS transporting and screening electron. The linear region at higher potential exhibits the properties of FTO substrate.
According to the Eq. (1) of Mott-Schottky, the Vfb values of different BL-TSs measured by the extrapolated method from the Mott-Schottky plots at gradient frequency are similar. Besides, the ND values are approximately equal, correlated to the eigen structure and electrochemical properties of photoanode, which calculated from the slopes of the middle linear region. Fig. 5 shows the Mott-Schottky plots at the different test frequencies of photoanodes treated by TiCl4 liquid epitaxy in two orders. The Vfb and ND values of each photoanodes are listed in Table S2.
Fig. 6a shows the Mott-Schottky plots of the BL-TS structures and BL above, and the plots were recorded and remeasured in the primordial electrodes [56]. The measurement was set at 1000 Hz in the potential range of −1.2 V to +1.0 V. The compact thin BL has more negative Vfb, which suggests a higher Fermi level. The lower conduction band position could be due to the VO·· energy level caused by self-doping of lower value ion. And Vfb of PBL is about −0.315 V vs NHE, lower than IBL obviously (Vfb=−0.135 V vs NHE). From the slope of Mott−Schottky plots, assuming the dielectric constant of titania, εr=55 [61], the PBS
structure has a higher electron concentration (ND) than IBS, listed in the right column of Table 1. Besides, the distinct functional bilayer (PBS) has a larger potential range of electron-hole pairs separation in the middle linear region (solid points), related to the excited electronic states (higher quasi-Fermi level). From the plots at higher potential, assuming the dielectric constant of FTO, εr=9 [61,62], the ND, FTO is (6.863 ± 0.0875)× 1020 cm−3.
The Fermi level difference between PBS and IBS is related to the concentration of self-doped low valence Ti ion in TiCl4 different sequence treatment, which is confirmed by the high resolution XPS spectra of Ti 2p in Fig. 6b. The details of peaks fitting are listed in Table S3. The low-binding-energy-shift Ti 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 peaks signify more doped Ti3+ with different treatments. The paved BL ensures the higher concentration of Ti3+ in the section of electron collection. And the infilled BL cannot guarantee the deposition of self-doped Ti3+, which lost at the prismatic surface of nanowire. The more disordered structure (IBS) increases the twists of transfer pathway for electron exportation. In consideration of the Vfb and ND of different BL-TS structures, the electron transfer capability of PBS exhibits better.
The various BL-TSs, BL and bare nanowire TS were then sensitized by the one-pot CdSxSe1-x QDs. The photocurrent–voltage (J–V) curves of all devices are shown in Fig. 7a. The basic device parameters including short circuit current (Jsc), open-circuit voltage (Voc), fill factor (FF) and power conversion efficiency (PCE) are listed in Table 2. The PCE of the device with PBS is 7.54%, far surpass than efficiency of the cell with IBS (4.61%). Comparing the device performance of two structures, the photocurrent changes significantly and the cell with distinct functional PBS structure exhibits higher short circuit current density and open circuit voltage than the cell with IBS. The current density and device FF increase could be attributed to the higher quasi-Fermi level and electron concentration (ND).
The device PCE is deeply influenced by FF, which reflects to the curvature of J-V curves [63]. To explore the increase in fill factor and Voc of the cells with different electron transfer structure, the equivalent series resistance (Rs) and shunt resistance (Rsh) of cell circuit are measured by the following Eq. (2):
= −⎛ ⎝ ⎞ ⎠
− R J V d d 1
(2)
The resistance–voltage (R–V) plots are derived from the J–V curves as shown in Fig. 7b. The resistances close to the open and short circuit in the curves are represented as Rs and Rsh, respectively.
The changes of equivalent Rs and Rsh could exhibit the electricity loss and leakage in solar cell, which reflect the electron transfer capability and the recombination properties. A small Rs will improve charge transfer and a large Rsh will improve the separation of photogenerated electron-hole. As in the identical Jsc and Voc model [64], a
small Rs reduces the cell voltage loss of I× Rs; and a large Rsh decreases the current loss of V/Rsh, both of which will lead the fill factor increase and PCE further increase. Compared with the resistances of the nanowire array TS and the bare BL structure in Table 2, the Rs and Rsh are subject to the ETL morphology. In general, the complete BL-TS structures (PBS and IBS) have a smaller Rs and larger Rsh than the ones of single functional layer (TS and BL). After TiCl4 treatment on the bare nanowire array skeleton, the infilled stuffing layer (of IBS) play the function of electron screening as blocking layer, thereby the circuit equivalent Rsh increase and the charge separation capacity of photoanode is improved. Therefore, considering the ordered morphology of each functional layer, the reduced Rs is attributed to the higher Fermilevel of distinct smooth ultra-thin BL, and the increased Rsh is attributed to the ordered electron transfer of neat nanowire array TS similarly.
For further investigation of the enhanced properties of the prepared different bilayer on the cell circuit, the sheet resistance (Rh) of photoanode and the charge transfer resistance (Rct) at the interface between photoanode and electrolyte are analyzed by the electrochemical impendence spectroscopy (EIS) with the simulated half-cell system in darkness. The simulation is beneficial to the investigation of TiO2 MOS/ QDs/electrolyte interface [65] and recombination properties [66]. The impendence in the high frequency region reflects charge transfer processes at the electrode and electrolyte interface with Cu2S/brass counter electrode. While the intermediate frequency region (10–100 Hz range) is assigned to the electron diffusion into the photoanode film and electron back reactions of the oxidized redox species at the photoanode/sensitizer/electrolyte interface [67]. The low frequency region (< 1Hz range) corresponds to electrolyte solution diffusion [68].
The Nyquist resistance complex plane plots of the several photoanodes above and the fitting equivalent circuit are shown in Fig. 8 and
the data in Table 3 show that all of the different TiO2 have relatively small Rh. The Rh values of BL-TS structures exhibit similarly and the one of IBS is bigger. The electron transfer capability is related to charge transfer resistance (Rct) and double layer capacitance (Cμ), and the recombination property is related to charge recombination resistance (Rr) and recombination capacitance (Cr) at the interface between photoanode and electrolyte. It can be seen that the Rct and Rr decrease significantly after TiCl4 treatment. Rct of the PBS structure is much smaller than the IBS, which is related to the difference in their Fermi energies changes as Vfb above. The smaller Rct means the photoelectron mass transfer and efficient extraction, leading the loss of photocurrent decrease. Then the difference can be observed on Rr similarly. The larger Rr means the voltage loss in the process of electron transfer is smaller, consistent with the results of Rsh.
Besides, the chemical capacitance (Cμ) is attributed to the electron density and Fermi level dependence [69]. The higher Cμ of PBS far means an improved Fermi level regarding the conduction band energy, which is correlated to the results of Vfb. In the case of the cell performance, the cell open circuit voltage (Voc) is equal to the difference between the Fermi energy and redox potential per unit charge [58]. Therefore, the Voc of PBL cells determined by Fermi level separation of
electrons and holes has an appreciable increase than the one of IBL, meaning the increased Cμ would motivate the Voc of device increase [70]. The cell exploiting PBS structure exhibits low Rct with high Cμ and Cr, correlated with the electron transfer capability and recombination properties and reflecting to the Jsc, Voc and FF increase, respectively.
The recombination lifetime is a measurement correlated with the statistic electron residency lifetime in the electron transfer process of cell open circuit and is calculated from the RC time constant of recombination. The electron diffusion length (LD), indicating the electron travelling distance before recombination, is calculated using the Eq. (3) following [71]:
=L L τ τ/r tD (3)
where L is the TiO2 ETL thickness, τr is the electron recombination lifetime (Rr Cr) and τt is the electron transport lifetime (Rct Cμ). LD is 0.93 μm for PBS and 0.74 μm for IBS. The longer electron diffusion length (LD) in PBS photoanode may also be the reason why devices show higher Voc due to the improved electron transfer ability.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
In the process of TiO2 photoanode modification, the improved electron transfer capability and decreased recombination is attributed to different TiCl4 chemical bath deposition. In terms of the changes of electron transfer pathway, flat-band potential (Vfb) and charge carrier concentration (ND), we study the different sequence effect of TiCl4 treatment on the improvement of electron transfer capability in QDSSC. According to the pathway changes of PBS and IBS structures, the posttreatment (IBS) would spoil the orderliness on micro- or nanoscale, of which the functional blocking layer was partly interfered by the formed relatively thick transfer skeleton. And on the other hand, the pretreatment (PBS) retained the orderliness of TiO2 nanowire skeleton. Besides, self-doped Ti3+ under different treatment primarily changed the electron transfer capability of photoanode. As a result, the more negative Vfb (−0.315 V, NHE) and higher ND (7.63×1019 cm−3) of PBS motivate the Voc and Jsc increase. The TiCl4 pre-treatment on photoanode (in PBS) reduces the resistances of charge transfer and recombination. Besides, in terms of energy level changes and impedance difference, the photoanode of distinct functional bilayer (PBS) has an
outstanding electron transfer and collection capability. The cell performance of PBS in CdSxSe1-x QD sensitization is improved significantly: the PCE is 7.54%, the Jsc is 18.93mA/cm2, Voc is 0.78 V and fill factor (FF) is 51.1%. The pre-treatment could persist more doped Ti3+ in photoanode modification and develop the electron transfer more efficiently.

metadata.abstractText: Of the photoanode in QDSSC, the TiCl4 solution treatment is widely used in mesoporous TiO2 surface modification. However, device performance amplification and electron transfer capability improvement of the two common preor post treatment are seldom yet. In this work, we explore the TiCl4 different treatments based on the typical TiO2 nanowire array photoanode for CdSxSe1-x QDSSC. In terms of the changes of electron transfer pathway, flat-band potential (Vfb) and charge carrier concentration (ND), we explored the inducement and increase of electron transfer capability and efficacy under different treatments. As for the influence of device performance, the more negative Vfb (−0.315 V, NHE) and higher ND (7.63× 10 cm) of PBS are beneficial to the increase of open-circuit voltage (Voc) and short-circuit current (Jsc). Therefore, the TiCl4 pre-treatment on photoanode modification (in PBS) is beneficial to reduce the resistances of charge transfer and recombination. The cell performance of PBS in CdSxSe1-x QD sensitization was improved significantly: the PCE was 7.54%, the Jsc was 18.93mA/cm, Voc was 0.78 V and fill factor (FF) was 51.1%.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
